title: 108_hr1106
content:
The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and authorizes the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey water distribution and drainage facilities to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by a certain date, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities. Additionally, the District must pay the net present value of remaining obligations or $280,000 to the United States. Amounts received will go into the Reclamation Fund. SEC. 5. TETON EXCHANGE WELLS.

In conveying the Teton Exchange Wells, the Secretary shall also convey Idaho Department of Water Resources permit number 22-7022 and all equipment appurtenant to such wells. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in this Act are fulfilled.

SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Prior to conveyance, the Secretary shall complete all environmental reviews and analyses as set forth in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY. SEC. 7. LIABILITY.

Upon conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages related to the conveyed facilities, except for negligence prior to the conveyance date. This does not increase liability beyond current provisions. 

SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS.

The District's eligible acreage for water from the Minidoka and Teton Basin Projects is increased to include all lands within the District as of the enactment date. This increase does not affect existing water contracts or State water law. SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING.

Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will start a drought management planning process in the Henry's Fork watershed with stakeholders. A report with a final drought management plan must be submitted to Congress within 18 months.

SEC. 10. EFFECT.

This Act does not affect existing rights or the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes' water rights. Conveyances under this Act will not impact any existing contracts or state laws regarding water use.
